The ideas in the reading can be slightly abstract or convoluted, but I'll try to share what I know is clear:

An earlier excerpt discussing the falling in love and it being beyond our control:


Falling in love, then, is a result of two things coming together: The longings which we have and the workings of our imagination.
The first draws us out of ourselves in search of another personl the latter intimates that a particular other person may be the one who can satisfy us. When these come together there is an amzing explosion of feeling. All our desires become focused upon that person and we look, dazzled, into those beloved eyes and see - if only for a while - the summation of our own existence and a new world of happiness. Although we have seen that those longings may be darker and more complex xthan we might like to believe.

...

His (Schiller) ode anticipation (to which Schubert gave on of his finest settings) describes the thoughts and emotions of a lover sitting by a window, awaiting the arrival of his beloved; it is probably based on an experience of his waiting for Charlotte von Lengefeld, the woman he was soon to marry. At every moment a slight sound or movement in the garden makes him think she has come at last - but no, he realizes it was only the wind in the branches of the tress, an apple dropping in the orchard, or the glimmer of a swan on the lake. But in his disappointment he enjoys a stronger and surer grasp of his love for her.

Why? Because anticipation, if conducted imaginatively (as it is here), doesn't just mean hanging around muttering: 'Where is she, when is she coming?' It involves thinking: 'Was that her footstep? I love the way she walks, she seems to carry herself so lightly.' that is it involves dwelling upon just what it is one is waiting for: the other comes alive under the benign influence of such thoughts. The lover, in this beautiful song, sees the whole of nature joining in his passion. He wants the trees to embrace her protectively, he wants the gentle breeze to enjoy the warmth of her cheeks; he begs night and silence to come quickly and provide the perfect sympathetic setting for their love. And he sees his own love as continuous with an eroticized nature: doesn't the wind kiss the flower; don't graps and pears swell under the loving influence of the sun?

The way the lover uses nature in this poetic example has, of course, a distinguished cultural history. It was a major obsession of the era to see in nature a reflection of human passions; this in turn was a special deveopment of the medieval view which regarded all of nature in symbolic terms. But the interest of the ode, for me (John Armstrong), does not lie in the specific images employed. Rather it is the way in which the lover spins out - and enlarges - his passion by aligning it with whatever comes conveniently to hand. This is the opposite of the climax and discharge of passion which brings feeling to a close. On the contrary, imagination in this case seeks to keep the passion growing in the mind of the lover.

...

stashed somewhere...


in that still and
settled place
there's nobody
but you
you're where i breathe
my oxygen
you're where i see
my view
and when the world
feels full of noise
my heart knows
what to do
it finds that still and 
settled place
and dances there
with you

:: edward monkton

Pyrosx shared this with me and I marveled a little while with just the melody, since this was a choral appreciation thingey.
But as I listened, I went to look for the translations and lo and behold, a very beautiful poem in the right context.
Here's sharing anyway.


Amor de mi alma

Garcilaso de la Vega

Yo no nací sino para quereros;
Mi alma os ha cortado a su medida;
Por hábito del alma misma os quero.

Escrito esté en mi alma vuestro gesto;
Yo lo leo tan solo que aun de vos
Me guardo en esto.

Quanto tengo confiesso yo deveros;
Por vos nací, por vos tengo la vida,
Y por vos e de morir y por vos
Muero.

Tr. Stroope

I was born to love only you;
My soul has formed you to its measure
I want you as a garment for my soul.

Your very image is written on my soul;
Such indescribable intimacy
I hide even from you.

All that I have, I owe to you;
For you I was born, for you I live,
For you I must die, and for you
I give my last breath.

“Soneta V”

Garcilaso de la Vega

Escrito está en mi alma vuestro gesto,
y cuanto yo escrebir de vos deseo;
vos sola lo escrebistes, yo lo leo
tan solo, que aun de vos me guardo en esto.

En esto estoy y estaré siempre puesto;
que aunque no cabe en mí cuanto en vos veo,
de tanto bien lo que no entiendo creo,
tomando ya la fe por presupuesto.

Yo no nací sino para quereros;
mi alma os ha cortado a su medida;
por hábito del alma mismo os quiero.

Cuanto tengo confieso yo deberos;
por vos nací, por vos tengo la vida,
por vos he de morir, y por vos muero.




Tr. Keith Beckman


Your every aspect is written on my soul:
and how much more I desire to write!
None but you has written, and I may only read,
that in reading, I might hide even from you.

In this I am and ever will be settled,
even though I see in you some few incompatibilities
(because I do not well understand what I believe,
already taking my fidelity for granted).

I was not born but to love you.
You my soul has cut to its measure:
it’s you I want as a cloak for my soul.

How much I must confess I owe you:
for you I was born, for you I have life.
Were it necessary, for you I would die;
and for you I do die.

if i could reach you
and show you
my fear
i would open your eyes
like the vastness that I would fade 
into
and gripped by every single droplet
of humidity like a strangle 
that tears me from you
i tremble with yearning
and fall into the light
tumbling through the nothingness
so that I can catch up with reality
and my arms that once held you
now reach out to find you


:: an adaptation

my brother says it in the most 'matter of fact' tone
when the bad things happen
they will always come at a go
you lose your job
or you hate what you are doing
someone close passes away
you relationship breaks down
you hate who you are or what you have become

one
big
steam roller
truck just rams you
or maybe
it seeps in slowly

depending
some spare some contemplation
while others come to a swift conclusion
the lack of meaning
or goals or sense or love or existence
despair mostly
that's how it is

me? I honestly disapprove(and even slightly despise)
at the lack of faith 
or hope
or courage
or strength

what would you do if you were put in their shoes?
The better option - is one which requires a degree of maturity - is to align infatuation with friendship, not with romantic love.

may i borrow poise, or structure

reject
connotations
post modern; contemporary form
at what point does it stray from adaptation

when does it then be mine?

the construction - that, is mine.
and then soon you, 
we, 
all will begin to see

the other parts in this creation
is not mine
and
mine
at the same time

Rain was coursing down the living-room window. J had gone into town an hour ago and I was about to head down the garden when a mass of black cloud hoved into view from the direction of Kallang and turned the drains into mad rushing streams and the canal a river.

No matter. I would do some painting.

It wasn't part of the plan. The plan was to finish the book or build an orphanage or even travel to corners of the world and naively think that I will somehow be able help someone less fortunate, earning a smile. But then, there was no harm resurrecting my dormant artistic skills before then. 

I dug the old stash in the corner for hard drawing paper, the ones that easily absorb water colour. Not that it mattered really, acrylic does little to paper. Found myself paint, the top hardened from age but the rudimentary shake - the way you would do a coke can to get it in someone's face,  was all it needed to tear the layer away. Two colours, green and yellow. 

After making a mug of green tea, settling down at the computer table wondering, why had I put this off for so long. The scent of old paper, the sticky plastic paint. I remember sitting in the corner of the art room, at seventeen and eighteen with a colour palette, dabbing dots on the pages as though it were a uniquely personal form of impressionism, attempting lines to no avail. The mix of the non-mixed paints as they merged while dabbing were fascinating, well at least the accents it created were. The edge of the cheap 1.30 paint brush, blunt from the constant tapping and stresses on the paper while I struggled with perspective, which till now, I barely am able to grasp. 

So I start off with the best 3D perspective outline of the orange in front of me. 'All circles are oval', Mr A used to say.

How often did I enjoy this gorgeous, furtive seclusion? In the bath mostly, or when I'm alone perhaps. Though it takes quite some time for anyone to truly understand this need for periodic isolation and the lack of it - while regularly dragging your senses to the shared reality, with the littlest of earthly distraction. 

And then I begin to dot in the shades of the whole orange.

Funny - well not funny in a funny way, to think that this was once what I had wanted to do with my life. Not oranges per se. But art in general. Abstract, mixed media, cross art forms, mixed multimedia art forms, there were more, the grander the better. Fit for a chapel exhibition or those museums with high white ceilings. Installations. Singapore never seem to create enough of that awe, that ambience and grandeur to make any (my!) majestic 'work of art' justifiable. I think it's the people. But that's my opinion. This dream though held no root to reality.

It was a bad painting. 

In truth, as always, overdone. Something about colours not blending so right. A slight miff and sigh and it was time to moved on to the next object, target. I don't like the word object. No, actually, I don't like the word objectify, object is safe.

So my second attempt was to be incredulously straightforward this time, to paint the wall behind the orange. Though now, thinking that blending a smooth cream colour wash over instead of the fail dots, (fail dots, heh) just didn't seem to be quite right without all the nuances of shadows and grainy paint work. I wasn't ever going to get this perfect balance. 

This just proves that reality was right along. Painting just wasn't going to be a sensible profession. Not if you wanted a decent salary and a decent non-dramatic, non-cliche gay life. Even the successful ones, the famous 'artsy' people you know about in Singapore's perpetual Arts Festival (I say that with a bit of irony and skepticism. I really do want someeday for the Arts here to take flight, better before I die) don't stay around very much, why or how or where or when, I do not know. 

My painting of the orange with dots created too much texture for its own good and the wall seemed too flat. They were both victims of a juxtaposed problem. The orange needed to be more smooth, the wall needed to be a bit dotty.

At this point, a man with no or little esteem would allow negative thoughts to enter his head, given that this man - I don't know, in Singapore, at what age do you call me a man, has in his mind many talents to share with the world who might, by some magically reason seem to need. But that was the whole point. To educate himself. To keep his mind alive, to keep it real. 

Just moments into this, I look up, and gaze through the window onto the neighbour's roof top. The bubble popped and I realise that, in my absence of the active world around me, the rain had ceased, the gentle soothing pitter-patter has subsided. No more rain to drown reality. The sun has come out and washed the world clean.

I tore the large attempt into little pieces, stamped it into the bottom of the waste paper basket, put on the bermudas and thongs and headed outside.

Life is a running, mortal narrative.

That's why they have soundtracks.
Heh.

Today
on the way back
was for the first time that
I've let my tears
fall


for the
most stupid but
possibly real reasons


the fear
of losing loved
ones in whatever ways
imaginable


the heart
broken and dread
that anticipating


needless
to say I fought
with myself over this


how much
can one truly
resist convince reject
fear


giving in
I compromised
at least it shows that I
love
and for that
i allow my weakness
to swim in
my resilience


for this
experience
will remind me of them
of him
and with it
form wisdom

So I can share some joy

We're cruising, love,
through northern days.

Days were covered,
in rain, blue and steel
beneath clouds

pillars, homes,
of pink and weathered gold,
wide light on the canal river:

it all passes so quickly,
left behind

in tears.

We thought before, or have-
The earth: does it swallow the sea?
The firmament: is it swallowed by the earth?

I spy, the blue sky
of the city, the durian 
of shimmers, imbue the afternoon sun

These, panels are sharp ornate crowns,
are domes, breasts of
a rusting, rustling city

All the rest is vague,
night without shadow, day
without light, glass you can't see through.

My love, this heart brought you
to these islands
scattered in heartlands,
to turn arounds of
gastronomic delight.

So now we are moving on
like silent ships
not knowing where we've been
or where we're going, alone
in a world of the rat race
and pitiless renewing rubbles.

It's best to shut down,
emulate drizzle and the morning dew.

We'll retire our eyes
and stifle our senses
until we emerge in the sun
and bury our teeth in sweet pristine escape

or madness.

we should love them as ourself.

Night falls. Or has fallen.
Why is it that night falls, instead of rising, like the dawn? Yet if you look east, at sunset, you can see night rising, not falling; darkness lifting into the sky, up from the horizon, sliding city lights burning. Maybe night falls because it's heavy, a thick curtain pulled up over the eyes. 

Non-picturesque; Non-Sequitur

Wanting to be with someone who's involved with someone else
is a lot easier. At the very least, you only have to prove your worth, relative to the 'other'. Rather than prove yourself to the person itself. You might be better than the other person but not good enough for the person.

It's a tad disheartening, to know that the people you love are willing to settle for less than they deserve.
It's always about the road less traveled and the easier way out.

2009: It's even so more unnerving to have yourself settle for less and trying to find the road less traveled.

At every person's life and at any point no matter how lonely,
They are loved. Perhaps not the way they would like it but they will still be loved.
The happiest people are just those that recognise that no matter how love comes,
that's the way it is.

"On earth there is nothing great but man; in the man there is nothing great but the mind."
:: Alexander Hamilton ::


:: Jacob wrestles with an angel ::

B: "I had a book of Bible stories when I was a kid. There was a picture I'd look at twenty times everyday: Jacob wrestles with the angel. I don't really remember the story, or why the wrestling -- just the picture. Jacob is young and very strong. The angel is ... a beautiful man, with golden hair and wings, of course. I still dream about it. Many nights. I'm ... It's me. In that struggle. Fierce, and unfair. The angel is not human, and it holds nothing back, so how could anyone human win, what kind of fight is that? It's not just. Losing means your soul thrown down in the dust, your heart torn out from God's. But you can't lose."



In Theatre Studies, we were taught semiotics, a system of signs that could help better understand the unfolding of events or the general unfurling of the mise en scene and interactions of actors/actresses on stage. In real life, reading theatre and people and  their scenarios are almost exactly alike, sans the intentional exageration. Except that in reality, there's a need to understand the existence of certain sign systems and what they mean anyway. How?  You just have to have had experience or to find all that out for yourself some way or other. As human beings, some of us are made more sensitive than others (more EQ lah. the dense ones lugi lor, but its a double edged sword nonetheless). By that, we are able to read signs that happen around to us. Of course, our outlook in life predetermines our interpretation of these signs and more often than not, this is a form of communication.

When it comes to verbal communication: needless to say, talking is a huge sign system all on its own. But in a sense, this issue is not the crux of what I'm trying to express anyway.
When it comes to body language: all sorts of sports, martial arts, dance and almost any form of movement characterizes a person.
Some of us are just better at reading and understanding these signs than others.

:: Cousin IT and I :: CNY ::
Had the weirdest dream in a long while, I only remember that there was some killing or loss of lives was involved. and it seemed like I was responsible for some of it. See, the odd thing was I woke up mid way and went back to sleep. But even as I was awake questions of whether it really happened surfaced and continued on into my sleep. So I kept asking the people in my dream. In the second dream, they were quite convincing that I've killed someone. and then the dream shifted on to someone getting a death sentence, concurrently with someone else with a (not very sensitive to say this out here) different offence. Now as I am awake, the thoughts of that reality are slowly seeping away. It's still raining.

Can anyone tell me how and what to look out for:
if I were a person who had 1 million dollars and I went to a place say Peru
and I was to focus my expenditure on education and hunger,
what could possibly go wrong.
(or why that would be a bad idea.)

::

I remember,
trying to swim in the sea in sentosa.
Training for the biathlon alone.
As I swum in the rocky waters:
the peripheral vision that surrounded my goggles
were mostly murky, semblances of brown.

My imagination went shotgun wild; thrashing.
I became afraid:
something might touch me,
something might drag me down,
or that I might touch the slimy bottom of the seabed.
It got my thoughts running, racing.

My chest tightens, breaths shorten and stutter.
I swum to shore and gave up water training.

That was fear.

That experience made me
now understand it on a different level.
While at this point
the reacquaintance of it is
intimate.
In contest-affirmation with fatigue.
But aloof.

conditions of love the philosophy of intimacy
=======================================================

We need to work with two ideas simultaneously:
the experience of love is open to change;
but only in some ways.

If we accept this premise of limitation,
we might still want to know to what extent
the experience of live is open to change
and to understand the mechanisms by which
such change can be brought about.

In thinking about dispositions we say that
they need to be fleshed out by our view of the world.
A disposition to be nice to another person will
govern our behaviour in concert with
our sense of what niceness consists of.

One of the ordinary tragedies of love occurs when
one person is well intentioned and well disposed
towards another, but has no adequate idea
of how to make the other person happy.

It is one thing to feel loving towards someone,
another to translate this feeling
into words and actions which make the other person
feel loved.

Love needs to be realized, made substantial,
in conduct if it is to be communicated.
Although this fact gives rise to many of
the problems of love it is also an avenue of hope.
For the ways we realize our intentions,
the way we turn them into behaviour, are more
open to change than the under-lying intentions
and dispositions themselves.

People can be better of worse at seeing opportunities
to make their affection apparent to the one they love.
They can be better or worse at seeing what the needs
or problems of the other might be;
at recognizing the impact of their own behaviour
on the other.

This has nothing to do with strength of feeling
or intensity of longing.

Instead it has everything to do with perceptual acuity
and imagination.

=======================================================

Philosophy Made Simple 'Bold lover, never canst thou kiss, though winning near the goal.' It's not the kiss but the moment just before the kiss that's the moment of real happiness. That's because the kiss, entails disappointment. Always. Inevitably. Without exception. Life is a painful process. Youth grows old, love grows cold. The journey is never as liberating as we anticipate. In a way, What most people really do want is relief --- not the fulfillment of desire, not even the renunciation of desire, but the eradication of desire. True happiness is impossible. The little bits of happiness that we do experience only make us more miserable by contrast. :: :: :: But his heart was open wide now. He has to acknowledge that he was no longer the same man he'd been at the beginning of his philosophical quest. He felt that he could see what no one else could see, not only his own inner turmoil, but the feelings of others.

"Those who lack courage will always find a philosophy to justify it." -Albert Camus Philosophy made Simple "My sister is an extraordinary woman. Not a great beauty, but something better -- she enjoys imperfections that make a work of art more striking. Like the extra limbs in some of Rembrandt's drawings." "What good is the Ding an sich ('the thing in itself') if you could never get your hands on it? It seemed to him now that all the great questions were unanswerable. The things that matter most to us are unknowable, and this unknowability weighed him down. Death, beauty, love, sex, pain. What can we know? How shall we live? What happens when we die?" "In moments like this, moments of bliss, as in sexual congress, the mind is steadied, focused on the present moment. Past and present converge, so to speak. The taste of this wonderful Saint-Cyr, for example, circumvents the senses and goes directly into the atman. The Veil of Maya is lifted." Oh, how much I savour it. In this sense, I'm happy, grateful even. For the blessings of gastronomical bliss.

the romantic vision "What is the world to our hearts without love? What is a magic lantern without light?" -goethe Love is a central theme in the autobiography we each write as we try to understand our lives; but we may feel that we become only more confused the more we reflect upon it. Love is closely connected with our vision of happiness; yet there is no one we are more likely to hurt, or be hurt by, than the person we love. It is all so transient... fleeting that we seem to know but not really know what love is; elusive mostly. It is as if saying it, or putting it in word is almost supercilious.

Maybe rain doesn’t seem so bad afterall.

Maybe rain doesn't seem so sad,
maybe pain doesn't seem so bad.
Like the day, all things come to a close,
so don't be unhappy or morose.
Just smile with glee,
just for me.

You see the smile I have on,
just for you.
A smile to chase away your blues.
If you'd only see the smile for you I once had.
Maybe, for once, rain isn't all the bad.

The sun solders on lines for the countenance,
while the living flesh grows older.
It is,
neither hot nor cold, just repeating
like a sort of prodigal lukewarmness;
indifference,
to just be alive, 
for my spirit, bolder.

So as the rain braids and skies coo 
to soothe the heart,
Silent screams
or sighs
like the muffled winds breathe.
Remembering that spirit where we had part,
Tucked in souls for the two of us,
beneath.





On finding this double coincidence of LOVE :
You need 2 people IN love.
You need them coincidentally to be in love
with EACH OTHER for the fairy tale ending.

When 2 people do this(communicate), it's like inventing a language together that no one else is let in on but imagine one party just decides to stop one day and pretend that it doesn't exist or he doesn't hear it anymore there's no way to prove then that the language was real.
